Description: Most acids involved with wine or fixed or nonvolatile (do not evaporate readily).
The amount of acetic acid in wine\, which at too high of levels can lead to an unpleasant\, vinegar taste.
Found in small quantities\, citric acid can add \freshness\"" and flavor to wine."
The amount of sugar remaining after fermentation stops. It's rare to find wines with less than 1 gram/liter and wines with greater than 45 grams/liter are considered sweet.
The amount of salt in the wine.
The free form of SO2 exists in equilibrium between molecular SO2 (as a dissolved gas) and bisulfite ion; it prevents microbial growth and the oxidation of wine.
Amount of free and bound forms of S02; in low concentrations\, SO2 is mostly undetectable in wine\, but at free SO2 concentrations over 50 ppm\, SO2 becomes evident in the nose and taste of wine.
The density is close to that of water depending on the percent alcohol and sugar content, and other variables like salt.
Describes how acidic or basic a wine is on a scale from 0 (very acidic) to 14 (very basic); most wines are between 3-4 on the pH scale.
A wine additive which can contribute to sulfur dioxide gas (S02) levels, wich acts as an antimicrobial and antioxidant.
The percent alcohol content of the wine.
Score between 0 and 10. Median of at least three expert taster ratings.
Factor with levels at quarter-gram intervals\, centered on the quarter gram where clustering occurs (e.g. [0.125,0.375) g / dm^3).
Factor with levels at quarter-gram intervals\, where clustering occurs (e.g. [0.25,0.50) g / dm^3)
Binary factor for upper outliers (x > 0.06677236 g / dm^3).
Binary factor for upper outliers (x > 0.1174665 g / dm^3).
Binary factor for free SO2 above 50 mg / dm^3\, the level at which it becomes noticable to the senses.
Total SO2 minus free SO2. This represents the amount of SO2 that has done \work\" by bonding to other compounds."
Free SO2 / bound SO2.
Sulphates / (total SO2 / 1000).
Residual sugar factored at 3, 5.5, 9.5, and 16.5 g / dm^3 where there appear to be natural troughs.
Numeric representation of quality ratings\, continuous but integers only.
Intuitively set factor levels based on slight observed clustering (split at 9.0, 9.75, 11.75, 13.25 %)
